SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Patients experience cerebral embolization during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB)
This study determined if alterations in temperature and/or PaCO2 can reduce cerebral and ocular embolization
METHODS AND RESULTS: Forty-four pigs underwent CPB: 24 animals at 28 degrees C, and 20 at 38 degrees C
The two temperature groups were randomized to undergo embolization (67-microm fluorescent microspheres) at either hypercarbia or hypocarbia
Before and after embolization, cerebral and ocular blood flow were determined at normocarbia
Reducing temperature or PaCO2 reduced cerebral and ocular embolization
Hypocarbia reduced cerebral embolization by 60% and 45% in normothermic and hypothermic groups, respectively (p < 0.0001 and p < 0.05)
Relative to normothermic animals, hypothermia reduced cerebral embolization by 37% under an elevated CO2 condition (p < 0.05), but not under hypocarbic conditions
Similarly, regardless of temperature, fewer emboli were delivered to the eye in hypocarbic animals (p < 0.05), but hypothermia did not reduce ocular embolization
CONCLUSIONS: Cerebral embolization is determined by both temperature and PaCO2 at the time of embolization
In CPB practice, reductions in temperature and/or PaCO2 during periods of embolic risk may reduce brain injury
